column7: Marshes, ditches and the margins of ponds throughout Britain[17].
column8: An almost cosmopolitan plant, found in most regions of the world including Britain.
column16: Eleocharis palustris is a PERENNIAL growing to 0.6 m (2ft) by 1 m (3ft 3in).  See above for USDA hardiness. It is hardy to UK zone 4.  It is in flower from May to July, and the seeds ripen from August to October. The species is hermaphrodite (has both male and female organs).  Suitable for: light (sandy), medium (loamy) and heavy (clay) soils. Suitable pH: mildly acid, neutral and basic (mildly alkaline) soils. It can grow in  semi-shade (light woodland) or no shade. It prefers  wet soil and can grow in water.
column20: Sap: usually of trees and usually but not always used as a drink.

column24: Bedding: Used as a lining for sleeping on or putting fruits etc on.,Stuffing: Used in making soft toys, mattresses, pillows etc.
column25: The plant has been used as bedding, for stuffing pillows and to make a pad for sitting on[257].
column27: Prefers slightly acid conditions, growing well in shallow water or muddy ground[200]. A very variable species, it is divided into a number of sub-species by some botanists[257].
column28: Seed - surface sow in the spring in pots standing in shallow water. When large enough to handle, prick the seedlings out into individual pots and plant them out in the summer. Division in spring.
